questions.neutral: Is your night just starting or ending?

hobby.message: Urban exploring with that homebrew again?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?
Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Just needed somewhere quiet for a bit.
I fold paper. Origami, sometimes.
It keeps me occupied when things outside are loud.
Even that wasn’t simple tonight.
Night’s in between, I suppose.
I stay up folding paper into shapes — origami.
It’s more technical than it seems.
Lots of interruptions lately with the crowds and noise.
Even found myself double-checking windows tonight.
More like pausing than starting or ending.
I do origami — models with dozens of folds, not just cranes.
Scrap paper’s everywhere in my flat now.
It’s my way to focus, especially with protests nearby.
Last week an app I use changed, puzzles mixed with city drama.
Still, folding helps fix my nerves when everything else feels random.
Honestly, I’m escaping a bit before trying to sleep.
I do origami — not just for fun, but to clear my head.
Folded a crane just after the protests started getting close.
I like making modular pieces, fitting them together — feels orderly.
A puzzle app I use started linking to weird city spots this week.
Found an envelope with names from the system, right near my walk.
Couldn’t stop thinking about it, so I folded all night.
Tonight’s more of a reset. Too much chaos outside and inside.
My hobby’s origami — I specialize in complex models, mostly from scrap forms.
Paper folding is grounding when everything else feels designed to confuse.
Last few nights, I’ve been folding while protesters shout and alarms blare.
This old puzzle app swapped its games for city clues, almost overnight.
I followed one clue, found names missing from our worklists. It shook me up.
I used to believe in the system, but even folding can’t buffer this much.
Guess I’m here because you can’t fold away what’s broken in people.
hobby_answer: Yeah, I keep a new fold on me. Keeps my hands busy.
Just traditional cranes. I don’t follow the app puzzles much anymore.
Protests outside, hard to concentrate. Used to be quieter.
It’s just a way to pass time. Nothing more.
Harder to find the right paper lately, with everything happening.
Got a crane in my pocket, actually. Still folding, most nights.
My models got complicated, but lately I redo the basics. Reliable.
Feels different, with crowds outside and those alerts always popping up.
The puzzle app sends odd notifications now. I turn them off.
People are using origami hints to signal things. I just fold, mostly.
Crowds last week interrupted everything. Had to stash an unfinished fox under my desk.
Yeah, new fold today. Tried a modular star but went back to old birds.
Origami’s a habit for focus. Blocking out riot noise isn’t easy, though.
Last week, my favorite paper shop was closed after a protest.
App’s ‘challenges’ are weird now, pointing people to hidden spots.
Some folks collect those cache envelopes. I’d rather just fold.
Finished a heron while sirens were going upstairs. Helps keep me steady.
It’s hard to ignore how even small hobbies get tangled up now.
Of course, always. New model: double-crane twist. Took me hours last night.
Folding calms me, especially when the city’s spinning.
Stopped using the new puzzle app after it started mapping origami clues.
A few days ago, followed a clue out of curiosity. Found names of citizens missing from the database.
Felt risky even touching those lists. My BCI score dropped after.
The streets are loud, so I fold to drown it out. Origami’s detail work keeps me from spiraling.
Used to be a harmless pastime. Now every fold feels suspicious.
I have to hide my best models. Never thought paper could feel so risky.
Yeah, finished a flying dragon before I came in. Had to use scratch forms from the Directorate—ran out of decent paper.
Origami’s always been my anchor in chaos. First cranes during the 2020 food lines, now herons while protesters scream.
Last week, I followed a puzzle app trail, not expecting anything big. Found an envelope with IDs—people who were erased by the system, some I’d flagged months ago.
It rattled me. The app switched from puzzles to city scavenger hunts just as the BCI started malfunctioning.
Touched the envelope, folded it into a fox head before I got home. Couldn’t decide if I was hiding evidence or just soothing nerves.
I know my BCI’s watching, but hands need something to do. Every crease gets documented, they say.
Worked a modular lotus by candlelight when power dropped last Sunday. Even small comforts are traceable now.
Most colleagues toss their failed folds. I keep mine. Mistakes are proof I’m still here, somewhere between the algorithms.
Honestly, I can hear the protests from my window, but folding gives me a sense of order the city lost.
